docs.lead_paragraph: More than 800 doctors in the Palm Beach County region did not work to protest increasing malpractice insurance costs. Organizers said the doctors were at a two-day conference on the problem. Hospitals added to emergency room staffs and rescheduled elective surgery. A panel named by Gov. Jeb Bush has voted to recommend a $250,000 limit on jury awards for punitive damages and pain-and-suffering in malpractice cases.

headline.main: National Briefing | South: Florida: 800 Doctors In Malpractice Protest

docs.abstract: More than 800 doctors in Palm Beach County, Fla, stay away from work in protest against increasing malpractice costs (S)
docs.snippet: More than 800 doctors in the Palm Beach County region did not work to protest increasing malpractice insurance costs. Organizers said the doctors were at a two-day conference on the problem. Hospitals added to emergency room staffs and rescheduled...

docs.lead_paragraph: Four days a week, Rachel H. takes the subway uptown, waves to the doorman in the large prewar apartment building where her psychoanalyst keeps his office, lies down on a burgundy leather couch and begins to talk. Ms. H., a 33-year-old graduate student, has heard all the jokes. She has listened patiently to friends who tell her she would be better off taking Prozac or trying yoga or leaving New York altogether to escape her obvious ''dependency'' on her analyst. She has endured teasing and incredulity. ''Don't you think that's so last century?'' asked one woman.

headline.main: Even in the Age of Prozac, Some Still Prefer the Couch

docs.abstract: Thousands of Americans still seek out psychoanalysis as way of dealing with their inner conflicts, gaining self-knowledge and finding personal fulfillment; psychoanalysis, once dominant in psychiatry, now stands on sidelines of a field where drug treatments and brief forms of talk therapy are the rule; those who seek out psychoanalysis believe that arduous, uncertain and often painful dissection of mental life such treatment entails offers something they can find nowhere else; Dr Henry Bachrach, analyst, comments; charts show demographics of patients in analysis (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two drug companies accused of conspiring to keep a less expensive generic version of a widely used blood pressure medication off the market have agreed to pay $80 million to settle an antitrust case, two state attorneys general said today. Under the settlement, the French-German drug maker Aventis Pharmaceuticals and the Andrx Corporation of Florida must pay $80 million to compensate consumers, state agencies and insurance companies that overpaid for Cardizem CD, according to statements released by the New York state attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, and the Michigan attorney general, Mike Cox.

headline.main: 2 Drug Makers Settle $80 Million Antitrust Case

docs.abstract: New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer and Michigan Atty Gen Mike Cox say Aventis Pharmaceuticals and Andrx Corp, accused of conspiring to keep less expensive generic version of blood pressure medication Cardizem CD off market, agree to pay $80 million to settle antitrust case; drug companies must pay to compensate consumers, state agencies and insurance companies that overpaid for drug; companies deny any wrongdoing and settlement does not involve any admission of guilt by them (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush is planning a major initiative to help small businesses obtain health insurance, but the proposal faces opposition from consumer groups and governors because the insurance would be largely exempt from state regulation. The proposal would allow small businesses to band together and buy health insurance through a national trade association or professional society. Through such arrangements, the White House says, small employers could pool their buying power and negotiate lower premiums, similar to those offered to large corporations.

headline.main: Bush Prepares Health Plan Aimed at Small Businesses

docs.abstract: Pres Bush plans major initiative to help small businesses obtain health insurance; initiative would allow them to band together and buy insurance through national trade association or professional society, ostensibly allowing them to pool buying power and to negotiate lower premiums similar to those offered large corporations; faces opposition from consumer groups and governors since insurance would be largely exempt from state regulation (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: 6 Retailers Plan Venture To Sell Music on the Web Six music retailers plan to announce today that they are joining forces to sell music that can be downloaded from the Web. The effort is motivated in part by the two-year decline in compact disc sales that has forced recording companies to cut costs and lay off employees and has damaged music retailers. Like the recording companies, music retailers are searching for new sources of revenue. Vinyl albums and cassette tapes have nearly disappeared, leaving retailers with the CD as their main option for selling music. But a proliferation of swapping on the Internet has led to a decline in CD sales. [Page C2.]

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A2-6 Powell Nearly Dismisses U.N.'s Report on Iraq Secretary of State Colin L. Powell came close to dismissing a crucial United Nations report on Iraq weapons, and said the United States would go to war alone if its divided European allies would not join the fight. The Bush administration will study the findings of the report, but Mr. Powell suggested it would be useless to give the inspectors more time. A1 Poised to Hit First and Alone The United States appears ready to carry out its new doctrine authorizing pre-emptive attacks on hostile states and terrorists who represent potential threats. While the administration would prefer to have the support of the United Nations, it has put the world on notice that it is prepared to act on its own. A12

docs.lead_paragraph: As he prepares to shepherd President Bush's agenda through the House, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert says he plans to split the emerging economic plan into individual bills and consult his own experts about adjustments to the White House approach. Mr. Hastert, who is beginning his third term as speaker, says experience has convinced him that the public can get a better understanding of actions to aid the economy if the legislation is piecemeal rather than one large costly measure subject to partisan attack.

headline.main: Hastert to Tackle Economy in Stages

docs.abstract: Speaker J Dennis Hastert says that in moving Pres Bush's agenda through House, he intends to split emerging economic plan into individual bills and consult his own experts about adjustments to White House approach; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The plan by Senator John B. Breaux for mandatory health insurance (''Why a Centrist (No Fooling) Wants Universal Insurance,'' Jan. 5) sounds good -- finally everyone in America would have health coverage. It asks, however, that the more than 40 million Americans who are not covered subsidize the health insurance business.
docs.abstract: Ashlyn Willis letter comments on Jan 5 article describing Sen John B Breaux plan for mandatory health insurance coverage

docs.lead_paragraph: SPARKS can fly when a grown son lives in his parents' home, but things were usually quiet around John and Terri Hamet's house in Lake Ronkonkoma -- as long as their son, Tom, now 22, took his medication for bipolar disorder. But there were frightening episodes, like the time in 1999 when Tom was driving on the Long Island Expressway and said he heard God on the radio asking him to prove his faith by stepping on the gas and weaving in and out of traffic. He eventually spun around and drove in the wrong direction until he was forced off the road by other drivers. He emerged physically unscathed but spent two weeks at John T. Mather Hospital in Port Jefferson until his mental condition stabilized.

headline.main: For the Mentally Ill, a Long Search for a Bed

docs.abstract: Article on dearth of spaces in state-licensed group homes, community residences or subsidized apartments for mentally ill adults in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, NY; Nassau County is working on state-financed program to streamline application process and Suffolk adopted similar program in July; group home and rooming house operators, patient Tom Hamet and his parents comment; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: PRICES have been falling in several parts of the economy, leading analysts to warn of the stultifying effects of deflation. Yet in one conspicuous area -- health care co-payments -- inflation can reach proportions that would alarm the International Monetary Fund. In most health insurance plans, doctor's visits and drug purchases do not come free. The insurers bear most of the cost, but patients also pay a small amount, in addition to their premiums.

headline.main: Inflation Is Alive In One Area Of Medicine

docs.abstract: Daniel Altman Economic View column on alarming rise in health care co-payments at time of low inflation; holds co-payments, once intended to discourage overuse of services, are increasingly becoming non-negligible way of passing rising costs to patients; graph (M)
